canonical_explanation.text: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides parallel. Key properties: opposite sides are equal, opposite angles are equal, consecutive angles are supplementary, and diagonals bisect each other. A quadrilateral is a parallelogram if any one of these conditions holds. The mid-point theorem states that the line segment joining the mid-points of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half its length.
rules: In a parallelogram: opposite sides are equal, opposite angles are equal
In a parallelogram: diagonals bisect each other
A quadrilateral is a parallelogram if: opposite sides are equal, OR opposite angles are equal, OR diagonals bisect each other, OR one pair of opposite sides is both parallel and equal
Mid-point theorem: line joining mid-points of two sides of a triangle is parallel to and half of the third side

questions.question_text: The sum of all angles of a quadrilateral is:
questions.explanation_correct: The angle sum of any quadrilateral is 360°. A quadrilateral can be divided into two triangles (2 × 180° = 360°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A quadrilateral's angles sum to 360°, not 180° (that's a triangle).

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram ABCD, if angle A = 70°, then angle B =
questions.explanation_correct: Consecutive angles in a parallelogram are supplementary. Angle B = 180° − 70° = 110°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adjacent angles in a parallelogram sum to 180°. So angle B = 180° − 70° = 110°.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, opposite sides are equal.
questions.explanation_correct: One of the fundamental properties of a parallelogram is that opposite sides are equal in length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is a defining property of parallelograms: AB = CD and BC = AD.

questions.question_text: The diagonals of a parallelogram:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallelogram, the diagonals bisect each other (each diagonal is cut into two equal halves at the intersection point).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other. They are not necessarily equal or perpendicular.

questions.question_text: In parallelogram PQRS, if PQ = 8 cm, then RS = ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite sides of a parallelogram are equal. PQ and RS are opposite sides, so RS = PQ = 8 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PQ ∥ RS and PQ = RS in a parallelogram. So RS = 8 cm.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, opposite angles are:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallelogram, opposite angles are always equal. Consecutive (adjacent) angles are supplementary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opposite angles are equal. It's the consecutive angles that are supplementary.

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral ABCD has AB = CD and AB ∥ CD. Then ABCD is a:
questions.explanation_correct: If one pair of opposite sides is both equal and parallel, the quadrilateral is a parallelogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The condition 'one pair of opposite sides equal and parallel' is sufficient to prove a quadrilateral is a parallelogram.

questions.question_text: If the diagonals of a quadrilateral bisect each other, it is a parallelogram.
questions.explanation_correct: If the diagonals of a quadrilateral bisect each other, it is sufficient to conclude it is a parallelogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diagonals bisecting each other is one of the conditions that proves a quadrilateral is a parallelogram.

questions.question_text: The mid-point theorem states that the line segment joining the mid-points of two sides of a triangle is:

options.text: Parallel to the third side and half its length
Parallel to the third side and equal to it

questions.explanation_correct: The mid-point theorem: the line joining mid-points of two sides is parallel to and half the length of the third side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mid-point theorem says the segment is parallel to the third side and exactly half its length.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram ABCD, angle A = angle C because:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallelogram, opposite angles are equal. Angles A and C are opposite angles, so A = C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A and C are diagonally opposite in ABCD. Opposite angles in a parallelogram are equal.

questions.question_text: In parallelogram ABCD, angle A = (3x + 10)° and angle C = (4x − 20)°. Find x:
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite angles are equal: 3x + 10 = 4x − 20. Solving: x = 30.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opposite angles in a parallelogram are equal: 3x + 10 = 4x − 20 → x = 30.

questions.question_text: In parallelogram ABCD, the diagonals AC and BD intersect at O. If AO = 5 cm, then AC =
questions.explanation_correct: Diagonals bisect each other. AO = OC = 5 cm. So AC = AO + OC = 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since diagonals bisect each other, OC = AO = 5 cm. AC = 5 + 5 = 10 cm.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a quadrilateral where AB = DC and AD = BC. Then ABCD is:
questions.explanation_correct: If both pairs of opposite sides are equal, the quadrilateral is a parallelogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides equal is always a parallelogram.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, D and E are mid-points of AB and AC. If BC = 10 cm, then DE =
questions.explanation_correct: By the mid-point theorem, DE ∥ BC and DE = BC/2 = 10/2 = 5 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mid-point theorem: DE = half of BC = 10/2 = 5 cm.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, if one angle is 65°, the adjacent angle is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: Adjacent angles in a parallelogram are supplementary. 180° − 65° = 115°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Consecutive angles sum to 180° in a parallelogram. So 180° − 65° = 115°.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a condition for a quadrilateral to be a parallelogram?

options.text: Both pairs of opposite sides equal
Both pairs of opposite angles equal

questions.explanation_correct: Equal diagonals do not guarantee a parallelogram (e.g., an isosceles trapezium has equal diagonals). The other three are valid conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rectangle has equal diagonals and is a parallelogram, but an isosceles trapezium also has equal diagonals. Equal diagonals alone don't prove parallelogram.

questions.question_text: In triangle PQR, X and Y are mid-points of PQ and PR. If XY = 7 cm, then QR =
questions.explanation_correct: By mid-point theorem, XY = QR/2. So QR = 2 × XY = 2 × 7 = 14 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mid-point theorem: XY = QR/2, so QR = 2 × 7 = 14 cm.

questions.question_text: The diagonals of a rectangle are equal.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle is a parallelogram with all angles 90°. Its diagonals are equal in length (can be proved using congruent triangles).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a rectangle, the diagonals are equal. This follows from the congruence of the triangles formed.

questions.question_text: In quadrilateral ABCD, angle A = angle C = 80° and angle B = angle D = 100°. Is ABCD a parallelogram?

options.text: Yes, because opposite angles are equal
No, because sides might not be equal

questions.explanation_correct: Both pairs of opposite angles are equal (A=C=80°, B=D=100°). This is a sufficient condition for a parallelogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal opposite angles is a condition for a parallelogram. Angles don't need to be 90°.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a parallelogram where AB = 6 cm and the perimeter is 22 cm. Find BC:
questions.explanation_correct: Perimeter = 2(AB + BC) = 22. So AB + BC = 11. BC = 11 − 6 = 5 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a parallelogram, perimeter = 2(l + b). 22 = 2(6 + BC), so BC = 5 cm.

questions.question_text: In a rhombus, the diagonals:

options.text: Bisect each other at right angles

questions.explanation_correct: A rhombus is a parallelogram with all sides equal. Its diagonals bisect each other (parallelogram property) and are perpendicular to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a rhombus, diagonals bisect each other at right angles. They are not necessarily equal (unlike a square).

questions.question_text: The converse of the mid-point theorem states: if a line is drawn through the ___ of one side of a triangle parallel to another side, it bisects the third side.
questions.explanation_correct: The converse states: A line through the mid-point of one side, parallel to another side, bisects the third side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The converse of the mid-point theorem starts with the mid-point of one side and a line parallel to another side.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a quadrilateral with AB ∥ DC and AB = DC = 5 cm. BC = 4 cm. Then AD =
questions.explanation_correct: Since AB = DC and AB ∥ DC, ABCD is a parallelogram. In a parallelogram, opposite sides are equal. So AD = BC = 4 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One pair equal and parallel → parallelogram → opposite sides equal. AD = BC = 4 cm.

questions.question_text: In parallelogram ABCD, angle A = (2x + 25)° and angle B = (3x + 5)°. Find angle C:
questions.explanation_correct: A + B = 180° (consecutive angles): (2x+25) + (3x+5) = 180. 5x + 30 = 180. 5x = 150. x = 30. Angle A = 85°. Since C = A (opposite), angle C = 85°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Consecutive angles: 5x + 30 = 180 → x = 30. Angle A = 85°. Angle C = angle A = 85°.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a trapezium with AB ∥ DC. E and F are mid-points of AD and BC. If AB = 12 cm and DC = 8 cm, then EF =
questions.explanation_correct: The line segment joining mid-points of the non-parallel sides of a trapezium is parallel to the parallel sides and equals half their sum. EF = (AB + DC)/2 = (12 + 8)/2 = 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mid-segment of a trapezium = (sum of parallel sides)/2 = (12 + 8)/2 = 10 cm.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a parallelogram. Diagonals AC and BD intersect at O. If BO = 5 cm and AO = 7 cm, find BD and AC:
questions.explanation_correct: Diagonals bisect each other: BD = 2 × BO = 10 cm, AC = 2 × AO = 14 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since diagonals bisect each other: BD = 2(5) = 10 cm, AC = 2(7) = 14 cm.

questions.question_text: Every rectangle is a parallelogram but not every parallelogram is a rectangle.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has all parallelogram properties plus all angles being 90°. A parallelogram may not have 90° angles, so not every parallelogram is a rectangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rectangle ⊂ Parallelogram. All rectangles are parallelograms, but parallelograms with non-right angles are not rectangles.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, D, E, F are mid-points of BC, CA, AB respectively. The triangle DEF is called the ___ triangle of ABC.
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle formed by joining the mid-points of the sides of a triangle is called the medial triangle. By the mid-point theorem, each side of DEF is parallel to and half of a side of ABC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The medial triangle is formed by connecting the mid-points of the three sides.

questions.question_text: The angles of a quadrilateral are in ratio 1:2:3:4. The largest angle is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of ratios = 10. Each part = 36°. Largest = 4 × 36° = 144°.

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A trapezium (or trapezoid) is a quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One pair of parallel sides defines a trapezium. Two pairs define a parallelogram.

questions.question_text: In a square ABCD, the diagonals intersect at O. Angle AOB =
questions.explanation_correct: A square is a rhombus (all sides equal), so its diagonals are perpendicular. Angle AOB = 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Square diagonals bisect each other at right angles. So angle AOB = 90°.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, D is the mid-point of AB. A line through D parallel to BC meets AC at E. Then:

options.text: E is the mid-point of AC

questions.explanation_correct: By the converse of the mid-point theorem: a line through the mid-point of one side parallel to another side bisects the third side. So E is the mid-point of AC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Converse of mid-point theorem: line through mid-point of AB parallel to BC bisects AC. So E is the mid-point.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram ABCD, AB ∥ DC and AD ∥ BC. If AB = 7 cm and AD = 5 cm, the perimeter is:
questions.explanation_correct: Perimeter = 2(AB + AD) = 2(7 + 5) = 24 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Perimeter of parallelogram = 2(length + breadth) = 2(7 + 5) = 24 cm.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a parallelogram?
questions.explanation_correct: A trapezium has only one pair of parallel sides. Rectangle, rhombus, and square all have two pairs of parallel sides and are parallelograms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trapezium has only one pair of parallel sides, so it is not a parallelogram.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, consecutive angles are supplementary.
questions.explanation_correct: Consecutive (adjacent) angles in a parallelogram are supplementary, meaning they add up to 180°. This follows from the parallel sides and transversal properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Co-interior angles between parallel lines are supplementary. In a parallelogram, consecutive angles are co-interior.

questions.question_text: The mid-point theorem applies to a ___ (geometric shape).
questions.explanation_correct: The mid-point theorem is a property of triangles: the segment joining mid-points of two sides is parallel to the third side and half its length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mid-point theorem is specifically about triangles and the segment joining mid-points of two sides.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a parallelogram with angle A = 60°. Find all four angles:

options.text: All of the above represent the same angles

questions.explanation_correct: A = C = 60°, B = D = 120°. The four angles in order ABCD are 60°, 120°, 60°, 120°. All options list the same set of angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opposite angles equal: A=C=60°, B=D=120°. The listing order varies but the angles are the same.

questions.question_text: ABCD has AB = CD = 6 cm but AB is NOT parallel to CD. Is ABCD a parallelogram?

options.text: No, we need both pairs of opposite sides equal
Yes, one pair of equal sides is enough

questions.explanation_correct: Having just one pair of opposite sides equal is not sufficient. We need both pairs equal, or one pair both equal and parallel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One pair of equal opposite sides alone doesn't make a parallelogram. Both pairs must be equal, or the equal sides must also be parallel.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, P is the mid-point of AB and Q is the mid-point of AC. If angle B = 50° and angle C = 60°, then angle APQ =
questions.explanation_correct: By the mid-point theorem, PQ ∥ BC. Since PQ ∥ BC and AB is a transversal, angle APQ = angle ABC = 50° (corresponding angles).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mid-point theorem gives PQ ∥ BC. Using corresponding angles with transversal AB: angle APQ = angle B = 50°.

questions.question_text: Show that the quadrilateral formed by joining the mid-points of the sides of a rectangle is a:
questions.explanation_correct: By applying the mid-point theorem to both diagonals of the rectangle, the quadrilateral formed by joining mid-points of the sides is a rhombus (all sides equal, as each side equals half a diagonal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mid-point quadrilateral of a rectangle is a rhombus. This follows from the mid-point theorem applied to the triangles formed by the diagonals.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a rhombus with angle A = 60°. The triangle ABD is:
questions.explanation_correct: In rhombus ABCD, AB = AD (all sides equal). Angle A = 60°. In triangle ABD: AB = AD, angle A = 60°. Since two sides are equal and the included angle is 60°, the other two angles are each (180°−60°)/2 = 60°. So triangle ABD is equilateral.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AB = AD (rhombus), angle A = 60°. This makes triangle ABD equilateral (all angles 60°, all sides equal).

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, if the diagonals are equal, it is a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A parallelogram with equal diagonals is a rectangle. This is because equal diagonals in a parallelogram force all angles to be 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal diagonals + parallelogram = rectangle.

questions.question_text: In the figure, ABCD is a parallelogram. P and Q are mid-points of AD and BC. Then BQPD is a:
questions.explanation_correct: P is mid-point of AD, Q is mid-point of BC. In parallelogram ABCD, AD = BC and AD ∥ BC. So DP = AD/2 = BC/2 = BQ, and DP ∥ BQ. One pair of opposite sides equal and parallel makes BQPD a parallelogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DP = BQ (half of equal sides) and DP ∥ BQ (parts of parallel sides). So BQPD is a parallelogram.

questions.question_text: A diagonal of a parallelogram divides it into:
questions.explanation_correct: A diagonal of a parallelogram divides it into two congruent triangles (by ASA or SAS criterion).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diagonal creates two triangles that are congruent by ASA (using alternate angles and the common diagonal).

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral has angle A = 90°, angle B = 90°, angle C = 90°, and angle D = 90°. It is definitely a:
questions.explanation_correct: All angles 90° makes it a rectangle. It's not necessarily a square (sides may not all be equal). Every rectangle is a parallelogram, but 'rectangle' is the most specific correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All 90° angles defines a rectangle. It could be a square (if all sides equal), but we can only confirm it's a rectangle.

questions.question_text: The line segment joining the mid-points of two sides of a triangle is equal to the third side.
questions.explanation_correct: By the mid-point theorem, the segment is equal to HALF the third side, not the full third side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mid-point theorem says the segment equals half the third side, not the full third side.

questions.question_text: In parallelogram ABCD, angle bisectors of A and B meet at P. Angle APB =
questions.explanation_correct: In parallelogram, A + B = 180°. Bisectors make angles A/2 and B/2. In triangle APB: angle P = 180° − A/2 − B/2 = 180° − (A+B)/2 = 180° − 90° = 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A + B = 180° (consecutive angles). In triangle APB, angle P = 180° − A/2 − B/2 = 180° − 90° = 90°.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, if the diagonals are perpendicular, it is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A parallelogram with perpendicular diagonals is a rhombus. (If the diagonals were also equal, it would be a square.)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Perpendicular diagonals in a parallelogram indicate a rhombus. A square has both perpendicular and equal diagonals.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, if D and E are mid-points of AB and AC, and DE = 4.5 cm, then BC = ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: By mid-point theorem, DE = BC/2. So BC = 2 × DE = 2 × 4.5 = 9 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mid-point theorem: BC = 2 × DE = 2 × 4.5 = 9 cm.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a parallelogram. If angle A = 4x and angle B = 5x, find angle D:
questions.explanation_correct: A + B = 180°: 4x + 5x = 180 → 9x = 180 → x = 20. Angle A = 80°. Angle D = Angle B = 100° (opposite to B? No: D is opposite B only if ABCD goes in order). Actually A is opposite C, B is opposite D. So angle D = angle B = 5(20) = 100°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4x + 5x = 180, x = 20. Angle B = 100°. Angle D = angle B (opposite angles) = 100°.
